metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This is a case about Houston police arresting individuals without warrants and detaining them withou...

target:
This is a case about Houston police arresting individuals without warrants and detaining them without probable cause. On December 5, 2016, two plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas. The plaintiffs on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated sued the City of Houston under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. Represented by private counsel and the Civil Rights Corps, the plaintiffs sought compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees. They claimed that the City of Houston regularly arrested individuals without warrants and detained them without probable cause hearings for longer than permitted by the United States Constitution.

The case was assigned to Judge Kennth M. Hoyt on December 7, 2016. The City filed a motion to dismiss the initial complaint. One of the named plaintiffs withdrew from the case and on March 1, 2017, the plaintiffs amended the complaint to add three more named plaintiffs. As a result, on March 7, the court denied the City's motion to dismiss on grounds of mootness because the filing of an amended complaint renders a prior complaint void and moots any motion to dismiss.

The City filed an amended motion to dismiss, which was denied on June 6, 2017. The court found that the defendants had essentially admitted that the facts the plaintiffs pleaded were true.

The case proceeded to discovery, and the parties engaged in lengthy discovery disputes. On August 30, 2018, the District Court issued an order stating that the City of Houston had intentionally destroyed evidence pertinent to the lawsuit. As a result, the Court held that inferences were appropriate: (1) throughout the class period, the City of Houston had a policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees who had not received neutral determinations of probable cause within the constitutionally required period of time; (2) throughout the class period, the City’s policymakers were aware of this policy; and (3) the City acted with deliberate indifference with respect to its unconstitutional policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees who hadn’t received probable cause hearings in the appropriate amount of time.

On December 11, 2018, the plaintiffs moved to certify their class. The first amended complaint detailed a single class of plaintiffs seeking compensatory relief, which applied to all those arrested without warrant and held for more than 48 hours without a prompt judicial determination of probable cause.

The plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint on December 13, 2018, which added a fifth named plaintiff. Additionally, this second amended complaint defined two classes seeking compensatory relief. The first subclass included all those arrested and held held by the City of Houston without a warrant or a judicial determination of probably cause for 48 hours or more, and the second subclass included those who were arrested and held between 24 and 48 hours.

In spring 2019, the District Court issued an order overruling a motion from the City that asked the Court to exclude certain documents that they claimed to be privileged from evidence. The plaintiffs filed a motion to compel the city to produce these documents, which was stayed by Judge Hoyt pending the City’s appeal. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals then vacated the District Court’s order with respect to one document, and denied the City’s claim of privilege in all other respects. Upon remand, the District Court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to compel.

In late June 2019, both parties filed motions for summary judgment. On July 3, 2019, Judge Hoyt granted the plaintiffs’ earlier motion for class certification. One week later, the City filed a motion to stay the case pending interlocutory appeal regarding the class certification issue, which was denied by the district court in early August. And, shortly after on August 8, 2020 the Fifth Circuit denied the defendants leave to appeal the grant of class certification.

At some during the summer of 2019, the parties began going through mediation and started settlement negotiations, and on August 13, 2019, a joint order to stay the case pending the finalization of settlement was granted.

In July 2020, Houston City Council voted to pass a settlement awarding the plaintiffs $1.17 million in exchange for indemnity. The court granted a joint motion for preliminary approval of the settlement on October 22, 2020.

On March 18, 2021, the court approved the settlement agreement determining it was fair, reasonable, and adequate for the class. The settlement payment was $1.17 million.

On August 9, 2022, the plaintiffs' attorney filed an unopposed motion for attorneys' fees and costs. On September 7, 2022, the court granted the motion for fees and costs. Attorneys' fees were $93, 241.28 (part of the total $1.17 million settlement). On December 20, 2024, the case was formally closed.

The plaintiffs on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated sued the City of Houston under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. Represented by private counsel and the Civil Rights Corps, the plaintiffs sought compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees. They claimed that the City of Houston regularly arrested individuals without warrants and detained them without probable cause hearings for longer than permitted by the United States Constitution.

annotation.explanation: December 5, 2016
42 U.S.C. § 1983 claim alleging violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments (warrantless arrests and detention without timely probable cause hearings).

annotation.explanation: Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution
annotation.checklist_item: Statutory or Constitutional Basis for the Case

annotation.explanation: Compensatory damages (class-wide compensatory relief)
Attorneys’ fees
Private counsel and Civil Rights Corps
Plaintiffs: Class Action

Plaintiff: Unnamed individual arrestees (initially two, later five named plaintiffs) suing on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated, alleging warrantless arrests and prolonged detention without prompt probable cause determinations.
Defendant: City of Houston (municipal government).
Alleged pattern of Houston police arresting people without warrants and detaining them without timely probable cause hearings beyond constitutional limits.

Filing and parties: Two plaintiffs filed in S.D. Tex. on Dec. 5, 2016 against the City of Houston under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for alleged Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment violations, seeking compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees.
Complaint filed initiating the case (Dec 5, 2016).

target:
This is a case about Houston police arresting individuals without warrants and detaining them without probable cause. On December 5, 2016, two plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas. The plaintiffs on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated sued the City of Houston under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. Represented by private counsel and the Civil Rights Corps, the plaintiffs sought compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees. They claimed that the City of Houston regularly arrested individuals without warrants and detained them without probable cause hearings for longer than permitted by the United States Constitution.

The case was assigned to Judge Kennth M. Hoyt on December 7, 2016. The City filed a motion to dismiss the initial complaint. One of the named plaintiffs withdrew from the case and on March 1, 2017, the plaintiffs amended the complaint to add three more named plaintiffs. As a result, on March 7, the court denied the City's motion to dismiss on grounds of mootness because the filing of an amended complaint renders a prior complaint void and moots any motion to dismiss.

The City filed an amended motion to dismiss, which was denied on June 6, 2017. The court found that the defendants had essentially admitted that the facts the plaintiffs pleaded were true.

The case proceeded to discovery, and the parties engaged in lengthy discovery disputes. On August 30, 2018, the District Court issued an order stating that the City of Houston had intentionally destroyed evidence pertinent to the lawsuit. As a result, the Court held that inferences were appropriate: (1) throughout the class period, the City of Houston had a policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees who had not received neutral determinations of probable cause within the constitutionally required period of time; (2) throughout the class period, the City’s policymakers were aware of this policy; and (3) the City acted with deliberate indifference with respect to its unconstitutional policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees who hadn’t received probable cause hearings in the appropriate amount of time.

On December 11, 2018, the plaintiffs moved to certify their class. The first amended complaint detailed a single class of plaintiffs seeking compensatory relief, which applied to all those arrested without warrant and held for more than 48 hours without a prompt judicial determination of probable cause.

The plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint on December 13, 2018, which added a fifth named plaintiff. Additionally, this second amended complaint defined two classes seeking compensatory relief. The first subclass included all those arrested and held held by the City of Houston without a warrant or a judicial determination of probably cause for 48 hours or more, and the second subclass included those who were arrested and held between 24 and 48 hours.

In spring 2019, the District Court issued an order overruling a motion from the City that asked the Court to exclude certain documents that they claimed to be privileged from evidence. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals then vacated the District Court’s order with respect to one document, and denied the City’s claim of privilege in all other respects. Upon remand, the District Court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to compel.

In late June 2019, both parties filed motions for summary judgment. On July 3, 2019, Judge Hoyt granted the plaintiffs’ earlier motion for class certification. One week later, the City filed a motion to stay the case pending interlocutory appeal regarding the class certification issue, which was denied by the district court in early August. And, shortly after on August 8, 2020 the Fifth Circuit denied the defendants leave to appeal the grant of class certification.

At some during the summer of 2019, the parties began going through mediation and started settlement negotiations, and on August 13, 2019, a joint order to stay the case pending the finalization of settlement was granted.

In July 2020, Houston City Council voted to pass a settlement awarding the plaintiffs $1.17 million in exchange for indemnity. The court granted a joint motion for preliminary approval of the settlement on October 22, 2020.

On March 18, 2021, the court approved the settlement agreement determining it was fair, reasonable, and adequate for the class. The settlement payment was $1.17 million.

On August 9, 2022, the plaintiffs' attorney filed an unopposed motion for attorneys' fees and costs. On September 7, 2022, the court granted the motion for fees and costs. Attorneys' fees were $93, 241.28 (part of the total $1.17 million settlement). On December 20, 2024, the case was formally closed.

annotation.explanation: August 30, 2018: the District Court issued an order finding intentional destruction of evidence and holding adverse inferences appropriate.

Court found the City intentionally destroyed evidence and drew adverse inferences that the City had a policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees without timely neutral probable cause determinations, that policymakers knew of it, and that the City acted with deliberate indifference.
Spoliation/adverse inference order issued (Aug 30, 2018) regarding intentional destruction of evidence.

The plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint on December 13, 2018, which added a fifth named plaintiff. Additionally, this second amended complaint defined two classes seeking compensatory relief. The first subclass included all those arrested and held held by the City of Houston without a warrant or a judicial determination of probably cause for 48 hours or more, and the second subclass included those who were arrested and held between 24 and 48 hours.

In spring 2019, the District Court issued an order overruling a motion from the City that asked the Court to exclude certain documents that they claimed to be privileged from evidence. The plaintiffs filed a motion to compel the city to produce these documents, which was stayed by Judge Hoyt pending the City’s appeal. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals then vacated the District Court’s order with respect to one document, and denied the City’s claim of privilege in all other respects. Upon remand, the District Court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to compel.

In late June 2019, both parties filed motions for summary judgment. On July 3, 2019, Judge Hoyt granted the plaintiffs’ earlier motion for class certification. One week later, the City filed a motion to stay the case pending interlocutory appeal regarding the class certification issue, which was denied by the district court in early August. And, shortly after on August 8, 2020 the Fifth Circuit denied the defendants leave to appeal the grant of class certification.

At some during the summer of 2019, the parties began going through mediation and started settlement negotiations, and on August 13, 2019, a joint order to stay the case pending the finalization of settlement was granted.

In July 2020, Houston City Council voted to pass a settlement awarding the plaintiffs $1.17 million in exchange for indemnity. The court granted a joint motion for preliminary approval of the settlement on October 22, 2020.

On March 18, 2021, the court approved the settlement agreement determining it was fair, reasonable, and adequate for the class. The settlement payment was $1.17 million.

On August 9, 2022, the plaintiffs' attorney filed an unopposed motion for attorneys' fees and costs. On September 7, 2022, the court granted the motion for fees and costs. Attorneys' fees were $93, 241.28 (part of the total $1.17 million settlement). On December 20, 2024, the case was formally closed.
target_paragraph: In spring 2019, the District Court issued an order overruling a motion from the City that asked the Court to exclude certain documents that they claimed to be privileged from evidence. The plaintiffs filed a motion to compel the city to produce these documents, which was stayed by Judge Hoyt pending the City’s appeal. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals then vacated the District Court’s order with respect to one document, and denied the City’s claim of privilege in all other respects. Upon remand, the District Court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to compel.

annotation.explanation: Appeal: City of Houston appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.
Spring 2019: the District Court overruled the City's motion to exclude purportedly privileged documents.
Documentary evidence: most disputed documents were ordered produced after appellate review, with privilege sustained as to only one document.
City’s motion to exclude documents as privileged; overruled by District Court (spring 2019).
Plaintiffs’ motion to compel production of documents; stayed pending appeal; Fifth Circuit vacated as to one document and denied privilege otherwise; on remand, motion to compel granted.
City of Houston ordered to produce the documents at issue in the motion to compel (following the Fifth Circuit’s ruling denying privilege in all other respects).
Spring 2019: District Court overruled the City’s motion to exclude documents claimed as privileged.
Fifth Circuit: Vacated the district court’s order as to one document and otherwise denied the City’s privilege claims.
Upon remand: District Court granted plaintiffs’ motion to compel.

target:
This is a case about Houston police arresting individuals without warrants and detaining them without probable cause. On December 5, 2016, two plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas. The plaintiffs on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated sued the City of Houston under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. Represented by private counsel and the Civil Rights Corps, the plaintiffs sought compensatory damages and attorneys’ fees. They claimed that the City of Houston regularly arrested individuals without warrants and detained them without probable cause hearings for longer than permitted by the United States Constitution.

The case was assigned to Judge Kennth M. Hoyt on December 7, 2016. The City filed a motion to dismiss the initial complaint. One of the named plaintiffs withdrew from the case and on March 1, 2017, the plaintiffs amended the complaint to add three more named plaintiffs. As a result, on March 7, the court denied the City's motion to dismiss on grounds of mootness because the filing of an amended complaint renders a prior complaint void and moots any motion to dismiss.

The City filed an amended motion to dismiss, which was denied on June 6, 2017. The court found that the defendants had essentially admitted that the facts the plaintiffs pleaded were true.

The case proceeded to discovery, and the parties engaged in lengthy discovery disputes. On August 30, 2018, the District Court issued an order stating that the City of Houston had intentionally destroyed evidence pertinent to the lawsuit. As a result, the Court held that inferences were appropriate: (1) throughout the class period, the City of Houston had a policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees who had not received neutral determinations of probable cause within the constitutionally required period of time; (2) throughout the class period, the City’s policymakers were aware of this policy; and (3) the City acted with deliberate indifference with respect to its unconstitutional policy of not releasing warrantless arrestees who hadn’t received probable cause hearings in the appropriate amount of time.

On December 11, 2018, the plaintiffs moved to certify their class. The first amended complaint detailed a single class of plaintiffs seeking compensatory relief, which applied to all those arrested without warrant and held for more than 48 hours without a prompt judicial determination of probable cause.

The plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint on December 13, 2018, which added a fifth named plaintiff. Additionally, this second amended complaint defined two classes seeking compensatory relief. The first subclass included all those arrested and held held by the City of Houston without a warrant or a judicial determination of probably cause for 48 hours or more, and the second subclass included those who were arrested and held between 24 and 48 hours.

In spring 2019, the District Court issued an order overruling a motion from the City that asked the Court to exclude certain documents that they claimed to be privileged from evidence. The plaintiffs filed a motion to compel the city to produce these documents, which was stayed by Judge Hoyt pending the City’s appeal. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals then vacated the District Court’s order with respect to one document, and denied the City’s claim of privilege in all other respects. Upon remand, the District Court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to compel.

In late June 2019, both parties filed motions for summary judgment. On July 3, 2019, Judge Hoyt granted the plaintiffs’ earlier motion for class certification. One week later, the City filed a motion to stay the case pending interlocutory appeal regarding the class certification issue, which was denied by the district court in early August. And, shortly after on August 8, 2020 the Fifth Circuit denied the defendants leave to appeal the grant of class certification.

At some during the summer of 2019, the parties began going through mediation and started settlement negotiations, and on August 13, 2019, a joint order to stay the case pending the finalization of settlement was granted.

In July 2020, Houston City Council voted to pass a settlement awarding the plaintiffs $1.17 million in exchange for indemnity. The court granted a joint motion for preliminary approval of the settlement on October 22, 2020.

On March 18, 2021, the court approved the settlement agreement determining it was fair, reasonable, and adequate for the class. The settlement payment was $1.17 million.

On August 9, 2022, the plaintiffs' attorney filed an unopposed motion for attorneys' fees and costs. On September 7, 2022, the court granted the motion for fees and costs. Attorneys' fees were $93, 241.28 (part of the total $1.17 million settlement). On December 20, 2024, the case was formally closed.
target_paragraph: In late June 2019, both parties filed motions for summary judgment. On July 3, 2019, Judge Hoyt granted the plaintiffs’ earlier motion for class certification. One week later, the City filed a motion to stay the case pending interlocutory appeal regarding the class certification issue, which was denied by the district court in early August. And, shortly after on August 8, 2020 the Fifth Circuit denied the defendants leave to appeal the grant of class certification.

annotation.explanation: Appeal: Defendants (City of Houston) appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.
July 3, 2019: Judge Hoyt granted class certification.
Early August 2019: the district court denied the City's motion to stay pending interlocutory appeal.
August 8, 2020: the Fifth Circuit denied defendants leave to appeal the grant of class certification.
Class certification was granted, confirming the case proceeded on behalf of a class of warrantless arrestees subjected to delayed probable cause determinations.
Cross-motions for summary judgment filed by both parties (late June 2019).
City’s motion to stay pending interlocutory appeal of class certification; denied by district court (early Aug 2019). Fifth Circuit denied leave to appeal (Aug 8, 2020).
July 3, 2019: Motion for class certification granted.
Early August 2019: City’s motion to stay pending interlocutory appeal (re: class certification) denied.
August 8, 2020: Fifth Circuit denied defendants leave to appeal the class certification order.
